#### WHAT WE STUDY

<h4 style="font-size: 12pt; letter-spacing: 1px; border-bottom: 1.5pt solid; line-height: 2; margin: 0; padding: .5pt;"> </h4>

###### .
###### .
###### .

<body style="line-height: 1.5;">
The Princeton University Biosociology Research Group was founded in 2016 by Professor Dalton Conley. In 2021, Professor Sam Trejo joined the lab. Broadly, the research group seeks to thoughtfully integrate genetic data and other biomarkers into sociological and demographic research. A key substantive focus of the lab is the complex ways in which social and biological factors interact to shape social, behavioral, and health outcomes across the life-course. Lab members have access to a wide range of data sets with genotyped respondents, ranging from detailed longitudinal studies to large-scale biobanks. While the lab has a particular focus on the analysis of genomic data, members of the lab analyze a wide range of biological data sources (e.g., DNAm, CRP, and other blood-based biomarkers). Completed and ongoing research projects include:
<br>
<br>
<ul>
<li>The social scientific analysis of polygenic scores, individual-level measures that summarize genetic</li> predisposition dispersed widely across the genome</li>
<li>Developing novel methods for detecting gene-environment interactions for complex traits</li>
<li>Identifying indirect genetic effects among social peers (e.g., genetic nurture)</li>
<li>Documenting patterns of genetic and phenotypic assortative mating</li>
<li>Leveraging within-family and quasi-experimental methods to estimate causal genetic effects</li>
<li>Exploring socioeconomic gradients in biological aging</li>
<li>The construction and application of genetic similarity proportions (also known as genetic ancestry proportions)</li>
<li>Grappling with ethical and regulatory questions raised by rapidly emerging genomic tools</li>
</ul>
<br>
<body style="line-height: 1.5;">
During the Fall 2025 semester, lab meetings will be held weekly on Tuesdays from 10:30am to 12:00pm. Please email Dalton and Sam if you would like to be added to the Biosoc listserv. While the lab is largely comprised of doctoral students from Princeton University’s Department of Sociology and/or Office of Population Research, graduate students and researchers from other academic departments and institutions are welcome.
